item.title: If your SSH config feels unmanageable, it probably is.
item.description:
Over time, a single SSH config file turns into a cluttered mix of work hosts, personal machines, GitHub setups, and cloud environments. It gets hard to read, harder to maintain, and nearly impossible to safely share or reuse. One typo can break everything, and finding the right section becomes a scroll-and-hope exercise.

That’s why I organize mine into a structured directory like this:

~/.ssh/config.d/
├── 100_work/config
├── 200_home/config
├── 300_personal/config
├── 400_github_work/config
└── 500_github_home/config

Each subfolder contains a focused config file, grouped by context and prefixed with a number to control load order. When you combine these files (often with a script or by using Include directives in your main ~/.ssh/config), they are processed in lexicographical (alphabetical) order. By prefixing each folder with a number, you ensure that configs are loaded in a predictable sequence 100_... first, then 200_..., and so on.
